##Activiation is an important concept: 
<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">In most connectionist models, networks change over time. A closely related and very common aspect of connectionist models is&nbsp;</span><i style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">activation</i><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">. At any time, a unit in the network has an activation, which is a numerical value intended to represent some aspect of the unit. For example, if the units in the model are neurons, the activation could represent the&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Probability" title="Probability" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">probability</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;that the neuron would generate an&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Action_potential" title="Action potential" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">action potential</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;spike. Activation typically spreads to all the other units connected to it. Spreading activation is always a feature of neural network models, and it is very common in connectionist models used by&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cognitive_psychology" title="Cognitive psychology" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">cognitive psychologists</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">.</span>

##Example: Handwriting recognition
<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">For example, a neural network for&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handwriting_recognition" title="Handwriting recognition" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">handwriting recognition</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;is defined by a set of input neurons which may be activated by the pixels of an input image. After being weighted and transformed by a</span><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Function_(mathematics)" title="Function (mathematics)" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">function</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 26.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;(determined by the network's designer), the activations of these neurons are then passed on to other neurons. This process is repeated until finally, an output neuron is activated. This determines which character was read.</span>
#Formal Science
<p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, 'Nimbus Sans L', Arial, 'Liberation Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: 26.3999996185303px; vertical-align: baseline; box-sizing: border-box; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"><a href="https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_science" title="Formal science" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-family: inherit; font-size: inherit; font-style: inherit; font-variant: inherit; font-weight: inherit; font-stretch: inherit; line-height: inherit; vertical-align: baseline; color: rgb(90, 54, 150); box-sizing: border-box; background: none;" target="_blank">Formal science</a>&nbsp; branches of knowledge that are concerned with formal systems, such as: logic, mathematics, theoretical computer science, information theory, Game theory, systems theory, decision theory, statistics, and some aspects of linguistics. Unlike other sciences, the formal sciences are not concerned with the validity of theories based on observations in the real world, but instead with the properties of formal systems based on definitions and rules</p>

<h1 class="title" style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 24px; font-size: 64px; line-height: 56px; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: 'PT Sans', sans-serif;">Design Patterns</h1><div class="content" style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); font-family: 'PT Sans', sans-serif; font-size: 16px; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;"><p class="ebook_ignore" style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-bottom: 16px;">In software engineering, a&nbsp;<span style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; font-weight: 700;">design pattern</span>&nbsp;is a general repeatable solution to a commonly occurring problem in software design. A design pattern isn't a finished design that can be transformed directly into code. It is a description or template for how to solve a problem that can be used in many different situations.</p><h3 class="ebook_ignore" style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-top: 32px; margin-bottom: 8px; font-size: 28px; line-height: 32px;">Uses of Design Patterns</h3><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-bottom: 16px;">Design patterns can speed up the development process by providing tested, proven development paradigms. Effective software design requires considering issues that may not become visible until later in the implementation. Reusing design patterns helps to prevent subtle issues that can cause major problems and improves code readability for coders and architects familiar with the patterns.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-bottom: 16px;">Often, people only understand how to apply certain software design techniques to certain problems. These techniques are difficult to apply to a broader range of problems. Design patterns provide general solutions, documented in a format that doesn't require specifics tied to a particular problem.</p><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-bottom: 16px;">In addition, patterns allow developers to communicate using well-known, well understood names for software interactions. Common design patterns can be improved over time, making them more robust than ad-hoc designs.</p><h3 style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-top: 32px; margin-bottom: 8px; font-size: 28px; line-height: 32px;"><a href="https://sourcemaking.com/design_patterns/creational_patterns" style="box-sizing: border-box; margin: 0px; color: rgb(68, 68, 68); transition: 0.25s; border-bottom-style: dotted; border-bottom-width: 1px; border-bottom-color: rgb(68, 68, 68); background: 0px 0px;">Creational design patterns</a></h3><p style="box-sizing: border-box; margin-bottom: 16px;">These design patterns are all about class instantiation. This pattern can be further divided into class-creation patterns and object-creational patterns. While class-creation patterns use inheritance effectively in the instantiation process, object-creation patterns use delegation effectively to get the job done.</p><div class="ebook_ignore" style="box-sizing: border-box; ##Usually a machine code language
<b style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">Machine code</b><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><b style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">machine language</b><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;is a set of&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instruction_(computer_science)" title="Instruction (computer science)" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">instructions</a>&nbsp;<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">executed directly by a&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Computer" title="Computer" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">computer</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">'s&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_processing_unit" title="Central processing unit" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">central processing unit</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;(CPU). Each instruction performs a very specific task, such as a load, a&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jump_instruction" title="Jump instruction" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">jump</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">, or an</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arithmetic_logic_unit" title="Arithmetic logic unit" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">ALU</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;operation on a unit of data in a&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Processor_register" title="Processor register" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;" target="_blank">CPU register</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;or memory. Every program directly executed by a CPU is made up of a series of such instructions.</span>
##To create an executable program

##Steps to create a compiler
<h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Intro</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">A typical compiler does the following steps:</p><ul style="margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 30px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;"><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Parsing: the source text is converted to an abstract syntax tree (AST).</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Resolution of references to other modules (C postpones this step till linking).</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Semantic validation: weeding out syntactically correct statements that make no sense, e.g. unreachable code or duplicate declarations.</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Equivalent transformations and high-level optimization: the AST is transformed to represent a more efficient computation with the same semantics. This includes e.g. early calculation of common subexpressions and constant expressions, eliminating excessive local assignments, etc.</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Code generation: the AST is transformed into linear low-level code, with jumps, register allocation and the like. Some function calls can be inlined at this stage, some loops unrolled, etc.</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Peephole optimization: the low-level code is scanned for simple local inefficiencies which are eliminated.</li></ul><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Most modern compilers (for instance, gcc and clang) repeat the last two steps once more. They use an intermediate low-level but platform-independent language for initial code generation. Then that language is converted into platform-specific code (x86, ARM, etc) doing roughly the same thing in a platform-optimized way. This includes e.g. the use of vector instructions when possible, instruction reordering to increase branch prediction efficiency, and so on.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">After that, object code is ready for linking. Most native-code compilers know how to call a linker to produce an executable, but it's not a compilation step per se. In languages like Java and C# linking may be totally dynamic, done by the VM at load time.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Remember the basics</h2><ul style="margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 30px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;"><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Make it work</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Make it beautiful</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">Make it efficient</li></ul><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">This classic sequence applies to all software development, but bears repetition.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Concentrate on the first step of the sequence. Create the simplest thing that could possibly work.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Read the books!</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Read the&nbsp;<a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0321486811" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; cursor: pointer; color: rgb(127, 58, 33);">Dragon Book</a>&nbsp;by Aho and Ullman. This is classic and is still quite applicable today.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;"><a href="http://rads.stackoverflow.com/amzn/click/0471976970" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; cursor: pointer; color: rgb(127, 58, 33);">Modern Compiler Design</a>&nbsp;is also praised.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">If this stuff is too hard for you right now, read some intros on parsing first; usually parsing libraries include intros and examples.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Make sure you're comfortable working with graphs, especially trees. These things is the stuff programs are made of on the logical level.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Define your language well</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Use whatever notation you want, but make sure you have a complete and consistent description of your language. This includes both syntax and semantics.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">It's high time to write snippets of code in your new language as test cases for the future compiler.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Use your favorite language</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">It's totally OK to write a compiler in Python or Ruby or whatever language is easy for you. Use simple algorithms you understand well. The first version does not have to be fast, or efficient, or feature-complete. It only needs to be correct enough and easy to modify.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">It's also OK to write different stages of a compiler in different languages, if needed.</p><h3 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 17px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Prepare to write a lot of tests</h3><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Your entire language should be covered by test cases; effectively it will be&nbsp;<em style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px;">defined</em>&nbsp;by them. Get well-acquainted with your preferred testing framework. Write tests from day one. Concentrate on 'positive' tests that accept correct code, as opposed to detection of incorrect code.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Run all the tests regularly. Fix broken tests before proceeding. It would be a shame to end up with an ill-defined language that cannot accept valid code.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Create a good parser</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;"><a href="http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Comparison_of_parser_generators" style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px; cursor: pointer; color: rgb(127, 58, 33);">Parser generators are many</a>. Pick whatever you want. You may also write your own parser from scratch, but it only worth it if syntax of your language is&nbsp;<em style="margin: 0px; padding: 0px; border: 0px;">dead</em>&nbsp;simple.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">The parser should detect and report syntax errors. Write a lot of test cases, both positive and negative; reuse the code you wrote while defining the language.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Output of your parser is an abstract syntax tree.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">If your language has modules, the output of the parser may be the simplest representation of 'object code' you generate. There are plenty of simple ways to dump a tree to a file and to quickly load it back.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Create a semantic validator</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Most probably your language allows for syntactically correct constructions that may make no sense in certain contexts. An example is a duplicate declaration of the same variable or passing a parameter of a wrong type. The validator will detect such errors looking at the tree.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">The validator will also resolve references to other modules written in your language, load these other modules and use in the validation process. For instance, this step will make sure that the number of parameters passed to a function from another module is correct.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Again, write and run a lot of test cases. Trivial cases are as indispensable at troubleshooting as smart and complex.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Generate code</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Use the simplest techniques you know. Often it's OK to directly translate a language construct (like an&nbsp;<code style="margin: 0px; padding: 1px 5px; border: 0px; font-size: 13px; font-family: Consolas, Menlo, Monaco, 'Lucida Console', 'Liberation Mono', 'DejaVu Sans Mono', 'Bitstream Vera Sans Mono', 'Courier New', monospace, sans-serif; white-space: pre-wrap; background-color: rgb(238, 238, 238);">if</code>&nbsp;statement) to a lightly-parametrized code template, not unlike an HTML template.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Again, ignore efficiency and concentrate on correctness.</p><h3 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 17px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Target a platform-independent low-level VM</h3><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">I suppose that you ignore low-level stuff unless you're keenly interested in hardware-specific details. These details are gory and complex.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Your options:</p><ul style="margin-bottom: 1em; margin-left: 30px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;"><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">LLVM: allows for efficient machine code generation, usually for x86 and ARM.</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">CLR: targets .NET, mostly x86/Windows-based; has a good JIT.</li><li style="margin: 0px 0px 0.5em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; word-wrap: break-word;">JVM: targets Java world, quite multiplatform, has a good JIT.</li></ul><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">Ignore optimization</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Optimization is hard. Almost always optimization is premature. Generate inefficient but correct code. Implement the whole language before you try to optimize the resulting code.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Of course, trivial optimizations are OK to introduce. But avoid any cunning, hairy stuff before your compiler is stable.</p><h2 style="margin-top: 0px; margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 19px; line-height: 1.3; font-weight: 400; word-wrap: break-word; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); font-family: 'Helvetica Neue', Helvetica, Arial, sans-serif;">So what?</h2><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">If all this stuff is not too intimidating for you, please proceed! For a simple language, each of the steps may be simpler that you think.</p><p style="margin-bottom: 1em; padding: 0px; border: 0px; font-size: 15px; clear: both; color: rgb(34, 34, 34); line-height: 19.5px;">Seeing a 'Hello world' from a program that your compiler created might be worth the effort.</p>

font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mimesis" title="Mimesis" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">mimesis</a></i><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;or&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Representation_(arts)" title="Representation (arts)" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">representation</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">. Art as mimesis has deep roots in the philosophy of&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aristotle" title="Aristotle" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Aristotle</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">.</span><sup id="cite_ref-Levinson5_16-0" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-Levinson5-16" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[16]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leo_Tolstoy" title="Leo Tolstoy" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Leo Tolstoy</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;identified art as a use of indirect means to communicate from one person to another.</span><sup id="cite_ref-Levinson5_16-1" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-Levinson5-16" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[16]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Benedetto_Croce" title="Benedetto Croce" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Benedetto Croce</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/R.G._Collingwood" title="R.G. Collingwood" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">R.G. Collingwood</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;advanced the&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Idealism" title="Idealism" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">idealist</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;view that art expresses emotions, and that the work of art therefore essentially exists in the mind of the creator.</span><sup id="cite_ref-17" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-17" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[17]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-18" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-18" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[18]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;The theory of art as form has its roots in the philosophy of&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Immanuel_Kant" title="Immanuel Kant" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Immanuel Kant</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">, and was developed in the early twentieth century by&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Roger_Fry" title="Roger Fry" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Roger Fry</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;and&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clive_Bell" title="Clive Bell" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Clive Bell</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">. More recently, thinkers influenced by</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martin_Heidegger" title="Martin Heidegger" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Martin Heidegger</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;have interpreted art as the means by which a community develops for itself a medium for self-expression and interpretation.</span><sup id="cite_ref-19" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-19" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[19]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/George_Dickie_(philosopher)" title="George Dickie (philosopher)" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">George Dickie</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;has offered an</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Institutional_theory_of_art" title="Institutional theory of art" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">institutional theory of art</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;that defines a work of art as any artifact upon which a qualified person or persons acting on behalf of the social institution commonly referred to as "the&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_world" title="Art world" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">art world</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">" has conferred "the status of candidate for appreciation".</span><sup id="cite_ref-20" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-20" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[20]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;Larry Shiner has described fine art as "not an essence or a fate but something we have made. Art as we have generally understood it is a European invention barely two hundred years old.</span><sup id="cite_ref-21" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-21" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[21]</a></sup>
##What's Art?
<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">Art is an act of expressing feelings, thoughts, and observations.</span><sup id="cite_ref-30" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-30" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[30]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;There is an understanding that is reached with the material as a result of handling it, which facilitates one's thought processes</span>

##Applied Arts
<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;On the other hand, crafts and design are sometimes considered&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applied_art" title="Applied art" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">applied art</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">. Some art followers have argued that the difference between fine art and applied art has more to do with value judgments made about the art than any clear definitional difference.</span><sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-14" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[14]</a></sup><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;However, even fine art often has goals beyond pure creativity and self-expression. The purpose of works of art may be to communicate ideas, such as in politically, spiritually, or philosophically motivated art; to create a sense of beauty (see&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aesthetics" title="Aesthetics" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">aesthetics</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">); to explore the nature of perception; for pleasure; or to generate strong&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Emotion" title="Emotion" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">emotions</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">. The purpose may also be seemingly nonexistent.</span>
##Visual Art
<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Visual_arts" title="Visual arts" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">visual arts</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">, which includes the creation of images or objects in fields including painting, sculpture,&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Printmaking" title="Printmaking" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">printmaking</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">, photography, and other visual media.&nbsp;</span>

<span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">A common contemporary criticism of some&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Modern_art" title="Modern art" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">modern art</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;occurs along the lines of objecting to the apparent lack of skill or ability required in the production of the artistic object. In conceptual art,&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marcel_Duchamp" title="Marcel Duchamp" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">'s "</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fountain_(Duchamp)" title="Fountain (Duchamp)" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Fountain</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">" is among the first examples of pieces wherein the artist used found objects ("ready-made") and exercised no traditionally recognised set of skills.&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tracey_Emin" title="Tracey Emin" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Tracey Emin</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">'s&nbsp;</span><i style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">My Bed</i><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">, or&nbsp;</span><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Damien_Hirst" title="Damien Hirst" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;">Damien Hirst</a><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">'s&nbsp;</span><i style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living</i><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;follow this example and also manipulate the mass media. Emin slept (and engaged in other activities) in her bed before placing the result in a gallery as work of art. Hirst came up with the conceptual design for the artwork but has left most of the eventual creation of many works to employed artisans. Hirst's celebrity is founded entirely on his ability to produce shocking concepts. The actual production in many conceptual and contemporary works of art is a matter of assembly of found objects. However, there are many modernist and contemporary artists who continue to excel in the skills of drawing and painting and in creating&nbsp;</span><i style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">hands-on</i><span style="color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;">&nbsp;works of art.</span>

##Purpose of Art
##Non Motiviated
<h3 style="color: black; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-bottom: 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; font-family: sans-serif; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"><span class="mw-headline" id="Non-motivated_functions_of_art">Non-motivated functions of art</span></h3><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;">The non-motivated purposes of art are those that are integral to being human, transcend the individual, or do not fulfill a specific external purpose. In this sense, Art, as creativity, is something humans must do by their very nature (i.e.,&nbsp;no other species creates art), and is therefore beyond utility.</p><ol style="margin-top: 0.3em; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 3.2em; list-style-image: none; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;"><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fine_arts" title="Fine arts" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Basic human instinct for harmony, balance, rhythm</a>.</i>&nbsp;Art at this level is not an action or an object, but an internal appreciation of balance and harmony (beauty), and therefore an aspect of being human beyond utility.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"Imitation, then, is one instinct of our nature. Next, there is the instinct for 'harmony' and rhythm, meters being manifestly sections of rhythm. Persons, therefore, starting with this natural gift developed by degrees their special aptitudes, till their rude improvisations gave birth to Poetry." -Aristotle<sup id="cite_ref-31" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-31" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[31]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Experience of the mysterious.</i>&nbsp;Art provides a way to experience one's self in relation to the universe. This experience may often come unmotivated, as one appreciates art, music or poetry.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"The most beautiful thing we can experience is the mysterious. It is the source of all true art and science." -Albert Einstein<sup id="cite_ref-32" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-32" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[32]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Expression of the imagination.</i>&nbsp;Art provides a means to express the imagination in non-grammatic ways that are not tied to the formality of spoken or written language. Unlike words, which come in sequences and each of which have a definite meaning, art provides a range of forms, symbols and ideas with meanings that are malleable.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"Jupiter's eagle [as an example of art] is not, like logical (aesthetic) attributes of an object, the concept of the sublimity and majesty of creation, but rather something else  something that gives the imagination an incentive to spread its flight over a whole host of kindred representations that provoke more thought than admits of expression in a concept determined by words. They furnish an aesthetic idea, which serves the above rational idea as a substitute for logical presentation, but with the proper function, however, of animating the mind by opening out for it a prospect into a field of kindred representations stretching beyond its ken." -Immanuel Kant<sup id="cite_ref-33" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-33" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[33]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Ritualistic and symbolic functions.</i>&nbsp;In many cultures, art is used in rituals, performances and dances as a decoration or symbol. While these often have no specific utilitarian (motivated) purpose, anthropologists know that they often serve a purpose at the level of meaning within a particular culture. This meaning is not furnished by any one individual, but is often the result of many generations of change, and of a cosmological relationship within the culture.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"Most scholars who deal with rock paintings or objects recovered from prehistoric contexts that cannot be explained in utilitarian terms and are thus categorized as decorative, ritual or symbolic, are aware of the trap posed by the term 'art'." -Silva Tomaskova<sup id="cite_ref-34" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-34" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[34]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li></ol>
##Motivated
<h3 style="color: black; margin-top: 0.3em; margin-bottom: 0px; overflow: hidden; padding-top: 0.5em; padding-bottom: 0px; border-bottom-style: none; font-size: 1.2em; line-height: 1.6; font-family: sans-serif; background-image: none; background-attachment: initial; background-size: initial; background-origin: initial; background-clip: initial; background-position: initial; background-repeat: initial;"><span class="mw-headline" id="Motivated_functions_of_art">Motivated functions of art</span></h3><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;">Motivated purposes of art refer to intentional, conscious actions on the part of the artists or creator. These may be to bring about political change, to comment on an aspect of society, to convey a specific emotion or mood, to address personal psychology, to illustrate another discipline, to (with commercial arts) to sell a product, or simply as a form of communication.</p><ol style="margin-top: 0.3em; margin-bottom: 0px; margin-left: 3.2em; list-style-image: none; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif; line-height: 22.3999996185303px;"><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Communication.</i>&nbsp;Art, at its simplest, is a form of communication. As most forms of communication have an intent or goal directed toward another individual, this is a motivated purpose. Illustrative arts, such as scientific illustration, are a form of art as communication. Maps are another example. However, the content need not be scientific. Emotions, moods and feelings are also communicated through art.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"[Art is a set of] artefacts or images with symbolic meanings as a means of communication." -Steve Mithen<sup id="cite_ref-35" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-35" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[35]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art as entertainment</i>. Art may seek to bring about a particular emotion or mood, for the purpose of relaxing or entertaining the viewer. This is often the function of the art industries of Motion Pictures and Video Games.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; white-space: nowrap;">[<i><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (July 2013)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>The Avante-Garde. Art for political change.</i>&nbsp;One of the defining functions of early twentieth-century art has been to use visual images to bring about political change. Art movements that had this goal<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dadaism" title="Dadaism" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Dadaism</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Surrealism" title="Surrealism" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Surrealism</a>,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_constructivism" title="Russian constructivism" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Russian constructivism</a>, and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_Expressionism" title="Abstract Expressionism" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Abstract Expressionism</a>, among othersare collectively referred to as the&nbsp;<i>avante-garde</i>arts.<blockquote style="overflow: hidden;"><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: inherit;">"By contrast, the realistic attitude, inspired by positivism, from Saint Thomas Aquinas to Anatole France, clearly seems to me to be hostile to any intellectual or moral advancement. I loathe it, for it is made up of mediocrity, hate, and dull conceit. It is this attitude which today gives birth to these ridiculous books, these insulting plays. It constantly feeds on and derives strength from the newspapers and stultifies both science and art by assiduously flattering the lowest of tastes; clarity bordering on stupidity, a dog's life." -Andr Breton (Surrealism)<sup id="cite_ref-36" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-36" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[36]</a></sup></p></blockquote></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art as a "free zone"</i>, removed from the action of the social censure. Unlike the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Avant-garde" title="Avant-garde" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">avant-garde</a>&nbsp;movements, which wanted to erase cultural differences in order to produce new universal values,&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Contemporary_art" title="Contemporary art" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">contemporary art</a>&nbsp;has enhanced its tolerance towards cultural differences as well as its critical and liberating functions (social inquiry, activism, subversion, deconstruction...), becoming a more open place for research and experimentation.<sup id="cite_ref-37" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-37" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[37]</a></sup></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art for social inquiry, subversion and/or anarchy.</i>&nbsp;While similar to art for political change, subversive or deconstructivist art may seek to question aspects of society without any specific political goal. In this case, the function of art may be simply to criticize some aspect of society.<div class="center" style="width: 1081.203125px;"><div class="thumb tnone" style="margin-left: auto; margin-right: auto; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-41" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[41]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-42" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-43" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[43]</a></sup>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_trafficking" title="Human trafficking" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">human trafficking</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-44" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-44" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[44]</a></sup><sup id="cite_ref-45" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-45" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[45]</a></sup>&nbsp;and a variety of other topics, such as ocean conservation,<sup id="cite_ref-46" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-46" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[46]</a></sup>&nbsp;human rights in&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Darfur" title="Darfur" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Darfur</a>,<sup id="cite_ref-47" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-47" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[47]</a></sup>&nbsp;murdered and missing Aboriginal women,<sup id="cite_ref-48" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-48" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[48]</a></sup>&nbsp;elder abuse,<sup id="cite_ref-49" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-49" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[49]</a></sup>&nbsp;and pollution.<sup id="cite_ref-50" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-50" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[50]</a></sup>&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trashion" title="Trashion" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Trashion</a>, using trash to make fashion, practiced by artists such as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marina_DeBris" title="Marina DeBris" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Marina DeBris</a>&nbsp;is one example of using art to raise awareness about pollution.</li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art for psychological and healing purposes.</i>&nbsp;Art is also used by art therapists, psychotherapists and clinical psychologists as&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_therapy" title="Art therapy" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">art therapy</a>. The&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art_therapy#The_Diagnostic_Drawing_Series_.28DDS.29" title="Art therapy" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Diagnostic Drawing Series</a>, for example, is used to determine the personality and emotional functioning of a patient. The end product is not the principal goal in this case, but rather a process of healing, through creative acts, is sought. The resultant piece of artwork may also offer insight into the troubles experienced by the subject and may suggest suitable approaches to be used in more conventional forms of psychiatric therapy.</li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art for propaganda, or commercialism.</i>&nbsp;Art is often utilized as a form of propaganda, and thus can be used to subtly influence popular conceptions or mood. In a similar way, art that tries to sell a product also influences mood and emotion. In both cases, the purpose of art here is to subtly manipulate the viewer into a particular emotional or psychological response toward a particular idea or object.<sup id="cite_ref-51" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-51" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[51]</a></sup></li><li style="margin-bottom: 0.1em;"><i>Art as a fitness indicator.</i>&nbsp;It has been argued that the ability of the human brain by far exceeds what was needed for survival in the ancestral environment. One&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_psychology" title="Evolutionary psychology" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">evolutionary psychology</a>&nbsp;explanation for this is that the human brain and associated traits (such as artistic ability and creativity) are the human equivalent of the&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peacock" title="Peacock" class="mw-redirect" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">peacock</a>'s tail. The purpose of the male peacock's extravagant tail has been argued to be to attract females (see also&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fisherian_runaway" title="Fisherian runaway" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">Fisherian runaway</a>&nbsp;and&nbsp;<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Handicap_principle" title="Handicap principle" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); background: none;">handicap principle</a>). According to this theory superior execution of art was evolutionary important because it attracted mates.<sup id="cite_ref-Dutton_52-0" class="reference" style="line-height: 1; font-size: 11.1999998092651px; display: inline-block;"><a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Art#cite_note-Dutton-52" style="color: rgb(11, 0, 128); white-space: nowrap; background: none;">[52]</a></sup></li></ol><p style="margin-top: 0.5em; margin-bottom: 0.5em; line-height: 22.3999996185303px; color: rgb(37, 37, 37); font-family: sans-serif;">The functions of art described above are not mutually exclusive, as many of them may overlap. For example, art for the purpose of entertainment may also seek to sell a product, i.e. the movie or video game.</p>
